author: Kymberli C.

description:
I'm not a super fan of hot weather in SF, and I'm certainly not a super fan of being in the mission when the hot weather hits (it's no wonder they all run for Dolores Park).  But there is one beautiful upside to it all, and that is ice cream (or in this case, ice cream's cult-ier cousin, gelato).  La Copa Loca is conveniently located between Mitchell's and Bi-Rite to ensure that no hipster is ever too far from from an emergency rush of cold, creamy sweetness.  Personally, I like Naia better for its wider gamut of unusual flavors, but they have a few gems here, like the oft-cited limoncello and banana nutella (I went with the giandujia, nut-flavored chocolate.  Which begs the question: why isn't all chocolate nut-flavored?  It's only sensible).  Oh, and they have an extensive sundae menu if you're up for something more intricate.

PS - The Crepevine chalkboards strike again!  Seriously, is there like one chalkboard guy in SF who does all these?
author: Wes M.

description:
Missionites are lucky when it comes to ice cream. Humphrey Slocombe has cornered the market on experimental flavors (think Salt & Pepper, Proscuitto, Olive Oil), and Xanath basically re-wrote the book on Vanilla. Bi-Rite Creamery is still the first destination for my out-of-town visitors, and I love my Chocolate-Dip Avocado from Mitchell's.

But for the most delightful and surprising range of exotic sorbets, La Copa Loca takes the cake! Dragonfruit, Lucuma, Soursop, Mamee Apple, Tamarind, Guanabana, Papaya, Kiwi, Mango, and a dozen more I can't even remember, all with that elusive, sticky, ice-chunk-free texture of a good sorbet. If you are looking for a novel fruity experience, this is your place.
author: Phoebe K.

description:
There is a book called "Eat Pray Love" that's been on the top of the New York Times' bestseller list for far too long, which to me is indicative of the general degradation of the modern literary standard but in any case is a book I'm reading for this book club I'm involved in. Anyway, I'm not trying to write a book report here so suffice it to say it's basically a diary of one woman's journey to find herself; you know, like every bitch is doing now that Stella got her groove back and that other middle aged white chick got a Tuscan sunburn or something. Anyway, there's nothing terribly groundbreaking about this book (except that somebody got paid MONEY to write it??) so the only reason I bring it up is that she spends a third of the book eating a ton of gelato. Not like, visiting cultural masterpieces or boning hot Italian dudes. Just eating gelato. Anyway.

You can read the book if you really want to know why because I honestly don't have the energy to recap all the lifetime original issues that landed this chick in Rome on a soul-searching mission, but suffice it to say she's not there to bone a bunch of Italian dudes or appreciate the architecture, she is there to eat a lot of gelato. So while I feel a mild irritation at the way this book highlights every weak and undesirable aspect of the feminine condition, it makes me crave delicious gelato like nobody's business. 

Which is funny, because I've never been a huge gelato person. I mean, it's sweet and delicious and I'll eat it, but I'm never like "Let's go get some gelato! [Insert three words of Italian that make no sense because I don't know Italian here.]" I mean, I've been to gelaterias in Italy, I've bought pints of Ciao Bella at my local fancy mart, and lord knows I've spent enough time in Belgano on 24th St. 
I've just never caught the fever, I guess.

But La Copa Loca: this is a fever I could catch. With flavors like fresh Limoncello and Banana/Nutella, I'd be happy to walk around eating gelato and overanalyzing my flaws all day. Well, that, but minus the overanalyzing of flaws, because it's a huge waste of time. 

And, La Copa Loca will bring their gelato to you, with a cheap and easy catering setup that will make your next party a hit. Plus, you'll have leftovers for days. And a scoop of Bacio sprinkled with ground coffee at about 3pm has a quite restorative effect on a person. Minus the post-feminist pity party.
author: Megan W.

description:
For the value (pretty tasty and decent portion for not too much dough), Copa is 2nd only to that place in Vienna that I made a point of going to each night while I was visiting... 

The unique flavors alone make this Mission spot worth the trip. (And never mind that it's the gelateria nearest to my Pot Hill home base). Melon, pineapple, blood orange...yummmmmmm!! Chocolate, amaretto, hazelnut? Yes please!
author: Miranda R.

description:
We wandered in from Panchitas No. 3 across the street, looking for dessert to cap an obnoxious evening. 22nd Street is looking like the place to be these days, and LCL is doing its part for the cause.

La Copa Loca (crazy cup!) has a fun name, a fun sign, a great selection of gelato and is open at 10 p.m. on a Tuesday. A waffle cup (!) with pistachio and amaretto gelato (I love nuts! That's what she said!) was $3.75 and I loved every bite with that flat little spoon.

Jose, our fun, saucy gelato scooper, was the best. He loves Barack Obama, and joked that the pic of his wife is coming down if he ever gets a photo with him.

Though I could get killed for saying so, I would take gelato over fro-yo any day. Go to La Copa Loca.
author: Tara R.

description:
Ay Ay Ay...where do I begin?  

First-La Copa Loca means The Crazy Cup.  Not sure what the crazy is about...but i'll give.  

Second-This place is open late and located in one of my favorite areas of SF-"Little El Salvador" in the Mission.  

Third Mi Amigo, Jose El Chaparrito, is the main reason why this place is getting 5 stars from me.  Service aside, this character is so worth the visit...well, as long as you are friendly and speak Spanish.  He was a stellar individual, and on 0527, he was ready to help the recently pupusa fed Yelp eating crew.  
Hint-To get on his fun side, just ask him about his ol pal OBAMA!

Fourth-I went behind the counter and was pretending to be Ms. Gelato.
Luckily, that's not my day job, and I stuck to what I know best...eating gelato!  

I sampled tiramisu, caramello, and hazelnut.  Oh yeah..one little crazy cup alright!   Overall, we took plenty of pictures, and had a wonderful finish to a busy night.  Although we did not get to meet the original owner, my experience was still wonderful thanks to Jose, my yelp pals Jeff H, Tara R, Anthony A, Angelo F, Carlos A, Lauren C, Linda T, and oh yeah...that crazy cup of gelato!
author: Flor D.

description:
Someone else mentioned that Gelato Milano ruined all other gelato for them and I'd have to agree.  

Had I not been the Gelato Milano, this place would have had five stars but their texture is just not quite as fine as it should be.  Flavors are good. . .the strawberry and mango were outstanding and the chocolate is deep and intense.  They also have many flavors that I want to go back and try such as kiwi and green apple.  

The copa isn't the only thing loca at this joint.  The owner was serving us and he's got that gleam in his eye of the mad scientist - crazy about what's he doing to the point of distraction . . . a good kind of crazy if that is possible.  

Oh and if you get a combo of three flavors it is HUGE and cheap. . .in fact I think he might have undercharged us somehow 'cause how can he afford to hook up that much gelato for $3.50???   Muy Loco!

The best thing I can say about Copa Loca is I can't wait to go back.
author: Lainie L.

description:
I'm glad I followed through on a recommendation to come here, because this lil corner shop is someplace I would not have noticed on my own.  La Copa Loca's main selling point is its homemade gelato in a variety of flavors, including ones that are sugar free and soy-based.  Cafe drinks, smoothies and shakes, along with pastries, cakes and snacks, are also sold here--enough to satsify anyone's sweet tooth.  I just wish they had more seating outdoors to enjoy it all.  

It's a great addition to Bombay, Bi-Rite, and Mitchell's when figuring out one's ice cream options in the area.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Non-hipster gelato in the Mission? Yes. You're reading that right.

Copa Loca is the most stripped-down, unpretentious gelato place ever, outside of certain gelaterias in southern Italy, of course.

Plenty of flavors to choose from (I'd guess at least 20), and the most amazing low prices. (See first paragraph.)

Even if it's not quite summer, or, in SF, just cold, Copa Loca gelato will serve you right.
author: Jeff H.

description:
AMAZING!!! 

This hard to find and wonderfully local place is now a preferred spot for ice cream/gelato... in line with Bi-Rite! We got a Banana Split and the Croccante... both delicious, but the Croccante was the best.  Caramel, chocolately crunchy yumminess....
author: Steph S.

description:
Yeah, apparently I'm in the minority but I do not feel this place has great gelato. It is basically the junk food version of gelato. What sets gelato apart from mere mortal ice cream, at least for me, is the contradictory combination of being airy yet creamy at the same time. The gelato was smooth and not inedible but I definitely will not send any friends here when they ask for a gelato recommendation. This place reminds me of Toy Boat in the Richmond district. Both places are fine if you just want to gather with friends and have some dessert. However, if you are specifically seeking out good dessert you will be sorely disappointed. 

The service knocks this place down even further. I will preface this by saying there was a misunderstanding but that really is irrelevant. Why? If you immediately launch into being a fucking asshole you are deservedly branded as fucking asshole. Misunderstanding or not. 

When I walked in I told him I'm not ordering yet since I was waiting for some friends. Apparently he thought I was just using the place to lounge around until my friends arrived. He told me to get out. Three times. After it finally sunk into his fucking thick head that I was actually going to order something later he left me alone. Plus, I ordered the profiterole dessert but wanted a different flavor than vanilla. So, he ends up giving me the profiterole dessert and a scoop of the chocolate separate. After I explained to him that he misunderstood he said no, that's what the profiterole dessert comes with. Asshole just didn't want to swallow his mistake. So I ended up getting stuck with two scoops of shitty gelato.

I usually don't care that much about service if the food is good. Chinese restaurants being a stellar example of this. However, the gelato really is poor quality and the service just adds to this.
author: Shawn T.

description: Their sundaes are a real treat!  More places should be half this inventive.  The gelato spaghetti is genius.
author: Chris A.

description:
Yeah, this place is in the strangest location.  But go, it's worth it.

As others have mentioned, this place has the best gelato in the city.  The owner is a great guy who'll chat with you if you like.

I've had many, many delicious flavors, and since you can't eat them all at once, I recommend getting them to pack a to-go container for you.  The price for that is very reasonable and you'll get to eat lots more!

Just be wary of any house guests or roommates that might spy your luscious stash.
author: Jeanine W.

description: This is honestly some of the best Gelato in the entire city.... Except the service sucks..... The lady who helped us out today was not friendly.... She obviously was pissed and had attitude.... I asked her if everything was ok and she just ignored me.... It was very perplexing because all we did was order gelato and some how we managed to piss her off... I understand that scooping ice cream sucks but hun you're in the service industry... Fake it!!! Regardless I live one block away and the Gelato is life changing gooood!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
After our heavy dinner at Sporks, of course I had to have my dessert to finish off my night. I took out my nifty iPhone and searched for gelato (even tho it was super cold) near the mission and La Copa Loca came up. 

They offer around 12-16 flavors and it's good but the flavors aren't super intense like what I'm used to. But it's still pretty good ice cream. Bi-rite is a lot better and it's pretty close by, I'll probably still go to Bi-rite for my dessert cravings.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I think the stars were not aligned last night. Panchita's was a let down and we came here hoping to end the night on a high note.

Which we did not. I tasted the hazelnut. Meh. I tasted the pistachio. No idea what it tasted like, but it wasn't pistachio and I am an expert on this flavor!! Settled for Scharf. chocolate bc I thought it was safe and I was too embarrassed to try a 3rd flavor.

It wasn't worth the calories and I tried to get my man to eat most of it so that I could enjoy my cone.

We won't be back bc there are too many other options for high-calorie tasty treats that actually taste good!
author: Shal J.

description:
Mmmmnnnnn.... delicious!  The best coconut gelato I've ever had.  Pair it up with the chocolate and you've got yourself one tasty treat.

Also... they have these crazy sundaes that look like spaghetti.  When people visit me I always take them for a funny sundae.
author: Amanda D.

description:
HOW WEIRD.  Gelato in the Mission.  Who knew?

The chocolate gelato is pretty darn good!
author: Daniel S.

description: This place is over priced and sub par. I specifically asked for the toddler scoop and when I got to the register they charged me for two scoops ($3 more than I should have been charged). I told her what I asked for and she refused to give me a refund. I will never go back here again. The gelato isn't even good. Such a let down.
author: Julie P.

description:
Delicious gelato. I recommend the blood orange, melon, pistachio, mmm so good, especially on a nice warm day :)

Update: Pumpkin and Zabajone are worth trying.
author: Glu C.

description:
This is the sweetness I crave after eating a bacon-wrapped hot dog or a burrito from Farolito.  What??  Can't I have a treat after my treat?  Don't you judge me!!

When I see that glowing neon ice cream cone in front of the shop, I get excited =)  My gelato treat is only a few blocks away!

My favorite flavor is the pistacio.  #1 baby!  Sweet, but not too sweet.  The smallest cup is the perfect size to satisfy my need for sugar.  Under $3 for the smal.  I've had better gelato before, but it's still really good! 

3.5 stars that round up to 4!
author: Liezl C.

description: This place is Great! We showed up right as they were closing, and they still let us try samples of different flavors. Besides being very reasonably priced, this place has EXCELLENT gelato. Having lived in Italy for a number of years, La Copa Loca took me right back! I got the yogurt (on recommendation from the woman that helped us) and Dulce de Leche, and both were amazing. Definitely go check this place out! If only they did Gelato with a Brioche, this place would be perfect!
author: Nick D.

description:
This is the best gelato I've had outside of Italy (I have not tried Gelato Milano yet).

I'm a sucker for a rich chocolate/tangy fruit combo and they always deliver.  Cheap too - two 2-scoop cups cost us less than $6.

My boyfriend tends to try something different everytime he goes.  Last night was pistachio and pumpkin - both marvelous.

They also have a wide selection of cakes and funny desserts like the mini-burrito, which is an all wheat crepe filled with gelato, dressed with fresh yogurt and fresh fruit.

Not to be missed.
author: cindy p.

description:
This joint got the Mitchell's Monkey off my back. Since I've started going steady with Mauro's crazy cups I can't even get psyched about ordinary plain old mortal ice cream any more. This guy, and his gelato are the real deal. He's a chef and it was his dream to own his own gelato shop. So you're able to eat desert, and at a reasonable price, that is a dream. Whoa. 

My recommendations are for the Bacio (chocolate hazelnut truffle), Gianduja (nutella!), and either Blood Orange or Fruits Of The Forest with Chocolate. If you're more adventurous, try the Pear/Ginger or Grapefruit. And if you're lucky he'll have a rare tub of tart but sweet Strawberry/Aloe. Dreamy.

Flava Update! Banana/Roche is an amazing fresh and unrotten banana gelato with swirls of Ferraro Roche.  Insane.
author: Jeremy W.

description: The worst service I've ever experienced.  Outright mean.  I patronized this seemingly-adorable artisan gelateria in the Mission, along with a 10 year old.   Upon requesting to taste the soy gelatos, as 10 year old is lactose-free, the bitchy scooper rolled her eyes and was palpably hostile.  The transaction became awkward as the clerk became ruder and meaner the longer we took to extract the poorly-spent dollars from our purse for a soy treat.  It was nice to come upon a treatery with wheat and dairy free desserts, but never again.  The server was so rude and horrible I didn't get a treat, so's not to linger nor give any more money to the Hostile Gelateria.
author: T L.

description: i love the nutella banana strawberry crepe  and hazelnut ice cream on the side yumy i love this place
author: Cari O.

description:
They advertise on their menu flyer hand-out thingie, the one that advertises all their indulgent cakes and what-not, something like "Egg-free? Dairy-free? No problem, just ask!"  They make all kind of creative sundaes for kids or the young at heart, and cakes of many shapes and sizes. From the pictures, they make a beautiful heart-shaped cake, I would love to ask them about making that one vegan.

I have only tried their vegan ice cream, they reliably have soy chocolate, and either soy vanilla or soy hazelnut.  AND, the entire front row is DAIRY-FREE!  Most of it is fruit sorbets, but as I mentioned, they also have vegan chocolate, vanilla, hazelnut, etc, although not necessarily all three of those flavors at once.  Another good thing about this place is that it stays open MUCH LATER than other ice cream places in the hood.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Very inexpensive for such crazy flavors.
I ended up getting Fat Tire beer flavored, goat cheese (with apricot chunks), and pumpkin in a waffle cone.
The goat cheese ice cream was amazing and went well with the pumpkin.
The Fat Tire...tasted like Fat Tire.
They have tons of fruit flavors too...of things I've never heard of.
That being said, I'm not sure if everything is gelato or ice cream...it kind of blurs the spectrum.
author: Johan E.

description: Mmmm, fancy gelato!  I had a scoop of Mango & a scoop of Kiwi.  They have some bigger fancier gelato based sundaes and banana splits -- they looked really good, but too big for my taste today!
author: Stephan W.

description:
ok, full disclosure, i haven't actually been to this joint yet. HOWEVER, i was at weird fish the other night (awesome) having just polished off an oyster poboy with my gal and a friend when the cute waitress convinced us to give a dessert a try. the truth is that i can't even remember what the dessert was, but the 'ice cream' that came with it was insane! so i asked her what we were dealing with here and she got all smiley and said 'oh, you like it? yeah, its soy vanilla bean gelato from copa loca.' 

WWWWWHHHHHAAAAAAATTTT? Soy vanilla bean gelato?!?!?!? holy ben and jerry's batman, this stuff was so over the top creamy that i about... 

nevermind.

anyway, go to weird fish and get poboys and get their dessert with the 'ice cream' or go to copa loca.

just do it man!
author: tommy p.

description:
Delicious!

I've walked past this place I don't know how many times, but I finally stopped in with a friend the other day.  Now that I know what I've been missing out on I won't be bothering to make the trip to stand in line on San Jose Ave.

Cheap prices, delicious flavors, and friendly service!
author: Gusty S.

description: Absolutely the best mango sorbet. Super when combined with their blood orange sorbet! Tasted the pomegranate sorbet today (a new flavor) and it is my new favorite. My son is a fan of the dark chocolate gelato, which we are all happy to help him eat - rich, dark, all chocolate. Other favorites are fruits of the forest sorbet and coffee gelato. La Copa Loca excels at traditional italian gelato flavors and all natural Mexican sorbet flavors. It's a find deep in the Mission.
author: Suzanne T.

description:
I've had other gelato, and this is the second time i've been here, and the flavors are second to none. What a variety of flavors!!! It's high quality gelato for a very reasonable price. When I went, the owner was behind the counter (Mauro was his name, don't ask me to pronounce it properly), and let me tell you he knows gelato, and also food in general (he's from northern italy originally). If you want authentic gelato, made the way Italians enjoy it, made as fresh as it comes, this is your place. 

Being from Long Beach, and yet to find a good gelato place (frozen yogurt craze down south), every time I'm in San Fran I'm going to hop on Bart and walk the two blocks. Wish I could try their gelato cakes!
author: Steven C.

description:
Great little place open late for a refreshing dessert!

The guy working there is really kind.
It's been a while since I've visited, but don't be fooled by the faded/marred sign. They have great gelatos that hit the spot.

While passing by today the guy was outside chatting with neighbors and greeting people passing by.

Will be back when I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Angel L.

description:
This gelato is a little icier than Gelato Classico's, and all of the gelato that I'm used to eating, but it's still excellent. The cool icy texture tends to melt fast on hot days, but also makes it an extra refreshing treat. And they make it themselves! I saw a worker scooping some of the fresh stuff in the back.

Sold by the scoop, if you buy one ($2), your second scoop will cost you only 75 cents more! Bonus points for self-serve complimentary cups of chilled water, and plentiful sidewalk seating.
author: Dave K.

description:
There's no lengthy review needed here. it's all good, the pannini's are good for a small lunch meal. The gelato is fantastic. The espresso is OK and they run a buy x get one free deal with the coffee based drinks. The owner is a nice guy.

Visit and you won't wanna go anywhere else anytime soon. Oh it's a half block from my job, I see the future, oh I'm a strung out gelato addict living on a street corner in the mission. Wonderful.
author: Tyler W.

description:
im not sure if i love it so much or hate it... definitely not like humphrys or bi-rite. maybe my tastebud isn't susceptible to gelatos that much... yes, probably that's the major reason. 

anywho. i was expecting much for what these reviews under 'la copa loca' says so, but once i got my gelato (and crepes) fix, i was hoping to jump for joy or be excited. NOT REALLY. i got the mint choco and stracciatella gelatos.with the ciocco crepe. although these didn't give me some FOODGASMS, i do believe that if you wash it down with ritual's coffee (specifically with my fave, chapadao), the whole thing works. overall, no hard feelings for my first time. 

maybe i DO have some taste aversions, as a super fan of both bi-rite and humphry.
author: Marc K.

description: I'm not a huge gelato fan, but they have tons of flavors and really friendly staff. My friend, who IS a huge gelato fan, loved it to no end.
author: Dina G.

description:
Two dollars for some uber scrumptious gelato in over twenty flavors!    Now that's loco.  I love the espresso one....mmmmm.

I'm never (ok, scratch that -- hardly ever!) going to the Bi-Rite ice creamery or Mitchell's again
author: Sid D.

description:
Gelizzle in the Mizzle.
There's three critical aspects to great Gelato.
First is flavor. La Copa Loca has many selections to choose from. My posse tried the Coconut, Hazelnut and the classic cost of entry, Chocolate. All were decent, but not anything to write Lucca about.
Most disappointingly, was the mouth feel or consistency. All three scoops were grainy or icy. Not what one would expect of great gelato.
Lastly, yes, the scoops are a decent size...and cheap as hell.
Certainly NOT crazy about the cup.
author: Mr. S.

description: My husband and I used La Copa Loca for our wedding dessert. They set their stand up at a bridal show and my mom and I walked by it and thought it was cool and grabbed the business card. From there we were corresponding with Mauro for over a year about havving them cater our wedding dessert portion. We got hazelnut and chocolate gelato cakes for our guests and everyone loved them! They looked amazing and tasted delicious! Could not have been happier!
author: Kelly F.

description:
Scrumpcious! I always have to drag people here: for SOME reason people are hesitant about a Mexican-owned gelataria. But the flavors are mah-volous and the quality top-notch. Grapefruit has always been my favorite. But everything is good. They have their usual flavors and rotate others into the mix. So last night I had to try the Pear and Ginger and it was perfect: not too gingery, mainly essence of pear. The owner is so friendly and calls out to people on the street to come in and taste for themselves.

AND they have a description out of the difference between ice cream and gelato...cuz you know you've always wondered.
author: Maya S.

description:
Ohh Lord... How I love gelato. Now look, I see that there are some gelato snobs on here, and well, that's just not my style. I've been all over Italy; I've had some incredible gelato. I sample more frozen desserts in one week than many do in a lifetime. I simply do not discriminate!
That said...

Every time I go to the US Bank ATM to deposit a paycheck (why aren't there more of those!?), my little treat for myself is to immediately withdraw a $20 (I never have money until payday), walk across the street, and enjoy a little frozen delight.

I've tried many of the flavors at La Copa Loca, and I have to say, my favorites are those of the chocolatey/ hazelnutty variety. Although the mango is amazing, also. The service is great, because they always let me sample as many flavors as I want, without giving me a dirty look. They even suggest flavors I might like based on the outrageously expressive faces I make! 

Oh, and the best part about this delicious gelato? It's cheap! And I also like their beverage variety. Those are pretty cheap, too. I've got a thing for those Juice Squeezes.
author: Victoria A.

description:
My friend and I found this gelato place on Yelp and we decided to give it a try. All I can say is everything is delicious. This is a little corner shop with only two tables outside for seating. 

The gelato is all homemade with a variety of flavors, including ones that are sugar free and soy-based. I tried their house speciality -- ice spaghetti pomodoro, which was totally cool..they have this little gadget where they can squeeze the gelato that looks like spaghetti.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Since I work in the Bayview, it is hard to run outside and get a sugar fix.  Well, you can get a fix but that is another story.  

The closest thing I could find during this hot spell is La Copa Loca.  It was like an oasis in this heat.  

One of the benefits of working in neighborhoods that few white people dare to tread is that they don't charge gringo prices.   Three bucks for a sugar cone and two scoops is fine with my broke ass.  

I know I drove the guy behind the counter crazy b/c I asked to try five flavors.  The melon was way cloyingly (I've always wanted to use that word) sweet.; Marco Polo's version is 100 times better.  The pistachio lacked chunks of the actual nut which is how I prefer it.  The coconut was also too sweet and again, I like chunks of fruit.  But then I tasted the chocolate and it was not too sweet and had a dense chocolate taste.  Now, I'd rather eat real pieces of bittersweet chocolate (preferably Blanxart Organic Dark Chocolate) rather than chocolate flavored things, but I'd return for two possibly three scoops of chocolate gelato.
author: Monica L.

description:
Stopped by there this weekend as it was new (I like trying new places) and looked interesting.

Tried the walnut gelato but didnt' like it.  Tasted nothing like walnuts and had very artificial flavor. 

Vanilla was just all right - nothing spectacular.  Was way to sweet.

Strawberry gelato was very nice - tasted refreshingly like strawberries.
author: Nick K.

description: Was just okay... nothing to write home about. Was expecting more crazy flavors.
author: Juliette C.

description:
On my Ice Cream Tour, La Copa Loca gets pretty good marks.  If you like a light, flavorful frozen treat, La Copa Loca is the place.  You won't find heavy, fatty, salty Ben and Jerry's type ice cream here, just light, delicious gelato!
Not my favorite freeze in the city, but a pleasant stop if you are (like me) on your way to a music lesson at the Community Music Center.
author: Kri B.

description:
This unlike any other gelato served in the City.. It's not super creamy nor is it super stringy and heavy.
It's sorta light and soft.  
In all honesty, it's like what gelato was like when i've tried it in France.. i know, gelato isn't French... whatever..
It's also exactly like this in Iran.. 
It was NOT like this in Italy..
What am i getting at?  
You want gelato like it's made in France and Iran?
Then this place is for you.
Basically this is my favorite gelato because i can eat even two scoops and i don't feel like i ate a brick.
Cinnamon, Passion Fruit, Blood Orange, Kiwi, etc.. It doesn't get any better than this.

This is also a Team Bomb Shit P**** meeting spot, so if you see a bunch of BMX bikes outside, beware of the BSP crew.  We're getting our twice a week Gelato Fix.
author: Kiya B.

description:
I had been searching for Amaretto Ice Cream...everywhere i had it twice when living in Atlanta at Cold Stones...and i never found it again. But lo and behold i found it here..and it was great! I had become a big fan of Gelato after having a cup at this Gelato  placeon 9th and Irving.

My roommies in My new place in the Mission had mentioned this place to me several times but they also mentioned it was on Capp St...I wasn't super thrilled to go but one sunny day i figured i take the 5min scroll to the Gelato shop...and it was amazing!

The owner is really cool and makes the gelato at the shop...so i respect that alot...and the Amaretto and Chocolate hazelnut gelato are to die for!

I have only complaint i went there the weekend of Carnivale...and some guy screwed up my order and then told me that i was wrong and that i had never had Chocolate Hazelnut at that place because they don't have it there...i was peeved! Plus it was hot!

But sure enough just last week i was taking a friend of mine from sausalito around the "hood" and i wanted to bring her there. I prayed that same guy wasn't there...There is a god! He was not there...it was the Owner...whew..close one.
author: Nia W.

description:
Richard brought me here and their ice cream is the same as the one that they have at the Ferry Building.

If ever your in the hood, you gotta check out this place...wait this is not FRO YO okay? Just Gelato at its best.
author: Malou C.

description:
This place is awesome.  My favorite flavor is melon, and if you're lucky, you'll get little pieces of fresh melon in your scoop!  What could be better?  

When I'm all meloned out, I go for the vanilla.  It may seem like a boring choice with so many exotic flavors to choose from, but it is amazing here!
author: Annie A.

description:
This is the real stuff. As authentic as it gets outside of Italy and with some  additional varieties for local tastes--such as soy and low-sugar-- as well.  

Service is friendly, and multilingual. They take credit cards, too, which is a big bonus as I don't usually carry much cash. 

They always have a good range of flavors, yet not too many (which would mean all the gelato sits around and gets old. Since LCL keeps their flavor variety limited, they sell fast and it doesn't get stale). 

I lived in several regions of Italy for four months and ate gelato at least once a day every day, often more--seriously. I got to know the best--and worst--gelaterias in my towns. La Copa Loca ranks up amongst the best I've had, even when compared to the ones back in Italy.  

And it's definitely the *best* I've had in the SF area. Ciao Bella? Ok, but expensive. Naia (sp?)? Ditto, and not as fresh. Bi-Rite? Not gelato, and although they have some good flavors I don't care to pay  $5 for a few scoops. 

Speaking of which, LCL's prices are quite reasonable--unlike Bi-Rite, where you pay more for the location and trendiness than the quality of the product itself. 

Given that we in the US can't get the *exact* same fruit and milk that is used in Italy, Mauro does a great job of finding alternative, high-quality ingredients when needed. (Some of his ingredients do in fact come from Italy, but things like Italy's fresh milk, eggs and fresh, ripe, sweet fruit either can't be imported or are prohibitively expensive). 

He also does some great snacks, from sandwiches to crepes to cakes for all occasions. Try one of the gelato and cake desserts sometime. 
 
Negatives? Maybe the coffee.. The espresso is just OK,  and could be improved. A ristretto shot, with nice thick crema Italian style would be awesome.  That's more a case of operator error than quality tho--you have to really really love espresso to make it well and most people operating an espresso machine don't know how to use it optimally.  
I won't lower my rating by a full star based just on that tho, since it's a gelateria, not a cafe, and the gelato is definitely 5 stars. 

Also, the location isn't great--I'm sure more people would know about it if it weren't in a less-travelled part of the Mission. But whether you're a local Latino or a transplanted hipster, you'll be welcomed there and are in for a treat.
author: Mike Y.

description:
This Gelato is good!  I would give it 5 stars but Gelato Milano in Berkeley ruined me for all other Gelato.  

I had the coconut and my wife had chocolate.  I'd recommend either of these.  

22nd street is fast becoming the nicest spot in the mission (all the way from the lone palm down to La Copa Loca).

Check it out!
author: sam p.

description: I came here because I was kind of in the area and there was a deal on Scoutmob.  The lady who helped me was super nice, especially since I didn't know what I wanted.  I tasted two flavors, and she probably would have let me try more.  I decided to get the Croccante and it had a scoop of chocolate gelato, a scoop of hazelnut gelato, hella whipped cream, hazelnuts, and chocolate sauce.  It was delicious.  There was a tad too much whipped cream, but that's a minor detail.  I would totally go back here and pay full price.  That thing was big enough to share with another person, too.  The neighborhood is a tad sketchy.
author: k h.

description:
Right off Mission, it's nice to get a treat here before walking around to view the murals (Humphry Slocombe is good for this also). Not a store for sitting and eating.

We arrived here on a foggy, almost misty, Sunday morning, 10:30 AM. It's always a good time for gelato. The server was attentive and kind. He brought out the gelato tubs for us and served us generous dollops.

I do not recommend the Cheese and Pear flavor. It's just a bad flavor combination, and the texture is chunky and unappetizing. The Soursop and Passion Fruit sorbets are very nice though, and my friend proclaimed the Dulce de Leche as the best she had in comparison to other stores.
author: Vivian W.

description: I love my neighborhood Copa Loca!  The staff (especially Mauro) is so friendly and they always have the best flavors...nothing better than gelato in the Mission on a sunny day.  Skip the lines at Bi-Rite for this great nook!
author: Allison D.

description: I like great gelato, friendly folks, and short lines in my neighborhood joint.  I also like the dairy free selection, though I usually just stick with a chocolate and berry mix.  5 stars every time.
author: Jon V.

description: Forget Bi-Rite and Mitchell's, La Copa Loca is a great place for hidden gelato. No long lines and the inexpensive route for late night desserts. The quality of the gelato is excellent and they have a great selection. Just like Bi-Rite and Mitchell's, they make there own products giving it a more authentic experience and taste. I recommend trying the cafe espresso, you wont regret it.
author: Rio A.

description: No doubt about it... best gelato in San Francisco ( or the whole Bay Area really).  I stumbled upon this little gem while in the Mission visiting a friend.  I even got to speak with the owner (who is from Italy) and he explained that everything is fresh and made from scratch on site.  LOVE it!  My favorite would have to be the pistachio, but seriously, everything I sampled was awesome!  I will definitely be back to support this small family owned business again.  And again and again!
author: Susan R.

description: The amaretto liqueur gelato is to die for and the strawberry is pretty damn yummy too.  Love the long hours that allow me to get my fix.  My mom still talks about this place from her visit last year.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Came here with friends a while back. Cute place, good gelato. I think I had the strawberrry and it was delish. Can't remember what my friends had but I know there was no complaints! The lady that worked there was really nice and let us have samples and was patient with us. Yum.
author: Brooke A.

description: Very pleased with Copa Loca.  Every bit as creamy and flavor-full as a singular ice cream I'd had in Spain 15 years ago, which I remember to this day.  It was a combination of plain yogurt and sorbet of fruit of the forrest.  Copa Loca recreated this concoction for me, and matched the original in its silky smooth punch.  Tart, tangy, sweet and creamy.  All at once.  Will definitely go back for more as they have a wide selection of flavors.  And the price is great !  Now, reluctant to give the five star rating I ask myself, what's not to like? Hmm.  (thought-full pause. . .)  It's  5 stars for Copa Loca!
author: Mark N.

description: Great icecream. Nice expresso. Really nice guy.  All good.  Go deh!
author: Joe D.

description: The owner of this place always gives me a hard time. I can't say I blame him. The first time I went in La Copa Loca he gave me shit for ordering the toddler scoop. He said I would get sick from so much gelato. But hey, I like the toddler size, so I get the toddler size. Then there was the time I had a black eye... That was awkward. The blood orange is great, but I'm a fan of all things blood orange. The owner seems nuts, but I tend to like crazy people. It's a nice little place.
author: Daniella C.

description: This is my favorite stop for ice cream (well, gelato) in the city. I recommend a combo of the lemon and the blood orange. Everything looks good, and the service is always friendly. A must on a hot day, but I visited today while out getting Christmas gifts. This is a secret worth sharing.
author: William W.

description: La Copa Loca fulfills its promise - a cup full of crrrraaaazy. I like the Bacio on a sugar cone for $2. And the passion fruit. Yum. But the super loca part isn't in the gelato itself. It's the guy who works the night shift. Secret giggles at your expense. Hmm. And it's in the glassed-in rotating carousel of sundae samples. Check out the pupazzo di neve and the pinocchio, the "pizza" and the "spaghetti." Crazy clown heads with sugar-cone hats in various states of meltdown, all stained with runny M&M dye. It's intense. Muy loca!
author: Katrina D.

description: Who would expect to find sensational gelato in the heart of taco territory? Italian-born Mauro Pislor uses original recipes and imports his ingredients, except the fresh fruit, from his homeland. His signature sundaes combine fruit, purees, and gelato to resemble whimsical animals, characters like Pinocchio, or 'spaghetti pomodoro.' The thirty or so flavors made daily run the gamut from pistachio to mango to pear to green apple. They even carry sugar-free varieties for dieters and diabetics. They're sold in special fluted Italian plastic cups or, if one portion isn't enough, it's available by the kilo which, considering how good it is, might last you a day and a half.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Parked near  Capp Street last night and walked by this place as I walked to Mission Street, then stopped in to check it out on my way back to my car.  I ended up buying a half kilo of 1/2 tiramisu and 1/2 chocolate.  The man who served me was very nice.  

The tiramisu really does have an excellent tiramisu flavor, don't know how they did it.  The chocolate flavor is pretty good too.

However, when I started eating it, it had a nice mouth feel but actually - and this is going to seem weird - it seemed a bit WATERY.  Tonight, I took it out and put it on the sideboard to warm up a bit (I like my ice cream soft, not hard and frozen solid), and I forgot about it until it had melted quite a bit.  The melted gelato was also very watery and thin, not thick and creamy like melted ice cream.

I don't mind this consistency, I've just never experienced it before.  Maybe real Italian gelato doesn't have as high a cream percentage as American ice cream.  I dunno.

I'm torn between 3 and 4 stars.  I gave it 3 because frankly I wouldn't drive across town for this, and would probably not rush to buy more, even if I were in the neighborhood.

Oh, the guy behind the counter seemed positively ANXIOUS to give me samples.  I had just had a taco and wanted to wait a while, so  I declined. But I thought it was nice.  A good way to see whether you like  a flavor before committing to buy a cone or more.
author: Alexandra D.

description: I sampled some gelato today at the Bella Pelle opening party with a mix of rose, tiramisu and jasmine but unfortunately, I thought it wasn't creamy enough. Have to give it a shot in their actual locations, perhaps it might be a tad better? They also cater for frozen cakes and sugar free items.
author: Yan M.

description: I'm puzzled as to why Stephan W. gave La Copa Loca only 3 stars.  Were the bigger gelato constructions (that he didn't try) just too big?  Was the mango too tangy?  The kiwi too sweet?  What's the problem here Stephan??  I think La Copa Loca does a great job with its gelato.  They are serving it before I get out of bed in the morning and make my neighborhood a happier place with laughing kids and smiling old folks enjoying the treats at Copa Loca provided sidewalk tables. They have even been spotted handing out free samples to people passing by.  What's not to like!?
author: Mikey P.

description: Before there was Humphrey Whatever and Bi-Rite Extremery there was this humble delicious gelateria in this neighborhood. Their treats are not salted. It's a place run by a nice Italian guy who serves Spanish-speaking and English-speaking customers alike, graciously. It reminds me of the Italians who brought gelato to Vienna and London and Paris - an ice cream place should be like this. It's not nouveau Frusen Gladje. It's just yummy. And I must admit it also meets my foodie standards: lots of flavors, lots of fresh intriguing taste and they have some sorbetti, some sugar-free stuff, some soy milk ones.
author: V. J. L.

description:
Meh definitely sums up my experience here last week.  I was very unimpressed with the service and the flavors.  I came here with the wife after dinner on a Friday night around 9pm.   We were the only customers.  There are a fair amount of flavors to choose from and we chose a few to sample before making a final decision.  The lady behind the counter was not warm or friendly at all.  She would give us a taste and then go back to doing something else.  Each time she had to get us a new flavor to try, she appeared annoyed.  Bear in mind, we each only sampled two flavors and NOBODY else was in the shop.

I got the chocolate and my wife had the straciatella.  The problem with ice cream in the states is that they just don't make it good at all.  We've been to Argentina and France and have had incredible ice cream/gelatos.  La Copa  Loca is fine if you've never had good stuff before but we have and this place disappoints.  The flavors weren't good and the texture was poor.  

I'll admit that I'm an ice cream snob and at the least, I can make much better stuff at home.  Not coming back here ever.
author: Scott L.

description: Only thing I've had here is the gelato, it's pretty much, hmmm.....AWESOME!  I had the pistachio and mi novia had the cinnamon, they were both really good.  The staff was friendly and will give you as many tastes as you want before you decide.  They also have sorbet, sandwiches which (according to my co-workers) are excellent and coffee.  Their scoops are very generous and of course go straight to your hips, fantastic!
author: Craig E.

description: I had heard a lot about this place so i decided to check it out. They had some interesting flavors, but overall the quality was not what i was expecting. If you want some real gelato, check out Ciao Bella Gelato in the Ferry Building. Now that's what gelato should taste like!
author: Audrey K.

description: Corner gelaterias that stay open late (10pm) are awesome. So when I stumbled onto this great little shack, my gawking, suburban ass almost ran into one of the ubiquitous Mission bikers. My bad. It's just that seeing anything open this late in the City is amazing and warrants a look-see. I played it safe and tried the hazelnut gelato in a waffle cone. Heavenly. Taking a gander, I noticed cakes, coffee and even some foccaccia. Surprise surprise, its not just a gelateria, but also a mini-bakery! Definitely coming back and trying the other gelatos and maybe the other stuff. Ok ok-- I know--I promise I'll pay more attention to the bikers next time.
author: Chris C.

description: Happened upon La Copa Loca by accident walking on 22nd from S Van Ness to Valencia. I had a bit of extra time before meeting my friend at the Marsh Theater so I stopped.  I ordered a strawberry cone, nothing exotic. I had a discussion with person who waited on my asking what the Spanish word for strawberry was.  I mean, I was in the MIssion, right?  And she was talking with a man and his young daughter in Spanish.  She told me fresa and I said, and it's fragola in Italian. I love all things Italian and speak some of the language. She smiled and said yes. I only noticed the extraordinary menu, restaurant history, and the owner's bio as I was happily munching my yummy cono alla fragola. I will be returning soon and often to try the other delicious creations.
author: Mauri S.

description: vegan gelato milkshakes.  I really can't think of anything more that needs to be said, aside from YES!
author: steve m.

description: Living almost a block away, I'm always tempted by Copa.  You can buy various flavors of their gelato in scoop or by the kilo.  They also have a bunch of creative sundaes.  Delicious and affordable.
author: Adrian N.

description: Mission ice cream crawl stop 2 of 4. Had passionfruit and guabana (sp? aka soursop) gelato for a mere $2.75. Not very creamy but decent flavour. Not a destination like Milano, but generally better balanced than Naia, though lacking that one great flavour to put it over the top. Fruit flavours seem to be the strength here.
author: Brad L.

description: Sweet and creamy and just like I remember in Italy... I went today for the first time, and I was impressed. I asked if they had any flavors with chocolate and hazelnut. This is a classic combination, and reminds me of little Italian Baci "kisses." At first she said, 'not today,' but then she went to the back and came back with a loving spoonful. It was divine. My friend had the espresso, and it was rich and creamy- a luscious treat for a Thursday afternoon. Have to go back for the sundae concoctions that are rotating around in the front... a merry-go-round of ambrosia.
author: Rebecca A.

description: The gelato is excellent.  It's every bit as good as what you find in North Beach, but instead resides in a neighborhood that actually gets hot enough to want ice cream.  Prices are great.  You can get a 20 oz. gelato smoothie for $4.75.  The selection isn't quite as large as some other stores, but it's still substantial, and no slots are wasted with such disgusting options as Beer or Rose flavored ice cream.  (Yes, I've really seen both of those.)  And it's open late enough to stop in after a nice dinner.  Keeper.
author: matt c.

description: ice cream cone out front, just like europe.  not the best gelato texture (missing the smoothness and density), i agree it's more like a sherbert.  little too icey for me (back row made with milk, front row without, thus = sorbet, which is actually a significant selection, i.e. tamarindo, etc).  sampled the mexican vanilla (slightly yellow) and the pumpkin, which had a nice flavor, hint of spice.  $2.25 single scoop on sugar cone.  didn't see any lucuma.
author: Rob C.

description: Super tiny but super yummy.  They have great gelato at a great price.  My only complaint is the lack of places to sit.
author: Laura W.

description: when it comes to gelato,( and basically everything else containing sugar) I have ABSOLUTELY NO self control. so yeah true to it's name, the gelato from here made me loca as predicted. I had to send my friend in for a second cone because i was too embarassed to ask for another myself. oh geez....i haven't actually been back since because i am protecting myself from... well, myself. and so as i pass it everyday on the way to work, the flavors and the colorful sign leer at me. one of these days, i'll break down again. I'm SURE
author: a w.

description: I've concluded that gelato ranks up there next to food/clothing/shelter on the list of life's neccessities. If you really want to get your fix and happen to be in the Valencia, La Copa Loca is the place to be. The shop itself  is small: a small freezer next to the door showcases a few delights and the chalk menu offers crepes and smoothies to entrance your sweetooth. But the main event, ladies and gentlemen, is the gelato...and I'm telling you: it  BEGS to be sampled from behind its glass case. At $2 scoop and $3 for two scoops (cones are ridiculously cheap too) you can afford to experiement (at least financially, you can deal with your trainer later).
author: Valerie C.

description: Another great gelato place.  There really can't be too many in my world.  Coffee, Gelato, Wine and Thin Crust Pizza... to start....
author: Today Y.

description:
best gelato in town,
thanks to La Copa Loca I feel less homesickness, gelato pizza and espresso are really a problem for italians abroad...
at least for gelato I am set now!

pistaccho and chocolate my favorite, highly recommended
author: massimo c.

description: Well to start let me tell you that this place is small but is a great place to get Ice Cream on the go. You must try the Mango and the Coconut they are so good. OMG I was so upset that I had not had it before. Well I hope you enjoy it. It is in the mission but it is worth  the trip.
author: Dee Z.

description: Not only does La Copa Loca have delicious and interesting ice cream flavors, they're very nice folks and once took the time out to help me when my motorcycle broke down in front of their shop.
author: David G.

description: Lets start by saying that Copa Loca is getting 4 stars instead of 5 because it's been a while since we've had genuine, homemade Italian Gelato and thus the comparison is not quite fresh in our minds.  Having said that, with over 20 flavors, half of them dairy free and 3 of them involving chocolate/vanilla/coffee soy gelato, you almost can't go wrong.  Cowboy suggest using yogurt as a base, combined with a fruit flavor, for tangy tutti frutti bomby action.  My favorite is the coffee soy gelato (ask for it if you don't see it up front) with oreo toppings.  You can sample every single flavor you want to and they are open until 10pm almost every day.  Service is always super.  Fun fact: St. Francis uses their gelato for their soy shakes and La Victoria on 24st carries their gelato as well.  the end.
author: Katherine K.

description: I've never been to their place, but I did have them at our wedding and it was a hit!  Mauro the owner was sooo nice and easy to work with.  I choose my 9 flavors, and he sent up his gelato stand at the reception, showed up at the right time, and people were lined up for the gelato!  From the four or five bites that one of my bridesmaids stuck in my mouth it was tasty!  Very reasonably priced too for an event.
author: Olive O.

description: Wow...they've got kalamansi (Filipino lemon) flavor!!! An excellent accompaniment to regular lemon (also very good). The mascarpone is great too. And some of the fairest gelato prices, too.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Ice cream has some wacky way of seeking me out. I was driving around the mission the other day, and saw a line out the door on a side shop. So I decided to drop in too. And guess what I found?! Delicious gelato. All the yummy Italian flavors like bacio, stracciatella and hazelnut. And the scoops are large!
author: Peter S.

description: After your super taco at Corneta, head over for 1 scoop banana and 1 scoop hazelnut in a waffle cone. Don't talk, don't breathe, just consume.
author: jenny m.

description: Better than Mitchell's. The coconut gelato is sensational. Also, try the hazel nut and banana flavors.... Really, it's all awesome. And my non-American boyfriend likes that they sell by the kilo.
author: Heather M.

description: What is the point in frozen yogurt and ice cream...when you could have rich gelato?  If you have never combined a bite of hazelnut gelato and a bite of chocolate gelato in your mouth, then you are missing out.  I can't believe that I had not gone to La Copa Loca sooner, but I guess I was not expecting to find a gelato place amongst all the taquerias.  They have plenty of flavors including Kiwi, Mango, Coconut, Tiramisu, Pistachio, and more common flavors like Strawberry and Chocolate for those of you with a more limited palate.  Who knew you could get decent gelato in the Mission?!
author: Diana T.

description: Best gelato I've ever had. I got the kiwi and orange blood while my friend got the tiramisu gelato. Orgasmic. Lots of flavors to choose from. Reasonably priced as well.
author: Amanda R.

description: Pistachio Gelato is a must have: I first met the owner of this location at a company event. Not only does he have this store location, but he also does mobile events as well. The gelato is by far the best in the city. I tried several different flavors I had not heard before, and they all were very satisfying. You will enjoy this charming place.
author: Jose d.

description: My hands down favorite gelato place in SF, and I've had lots of gelato! So happy that they serve hazelnut gelato.
author: Lilia A.

description: Copa Loca has some great attributes, it's only a block away from my house, is open late and isn't pricey.  But folks, I hate to say this.. but this isn't earth-shattering gelato.    Their gelato is runny and there was  a bit of a tinny aftertaste that just wasn't right the last time I tried their chocolate and vanilla scoops.   So.. although the staff is nice and the hours are good, it probably isn't worth trekking across town for...
author: Yas E.

description: loved this place! There aren't seats to sit so its a grab your treat and jet type of place. I ordered the mango sundae cup and it was a little overly mango-ey. But their gelato is good, decent sized.. Large mango chunks were scattered throughtout my sundae cup too. I would just suggest asking for them to go easy on the mango sauce.
author: Carrie W.

description: Good stuff. The chocolate chip is awesome, and unlike the Castro place, this treat is reasonably priced at $2 a cup.
author: Gibson V.

description:
Amazing gelato.  Its always a toss up whether to go here or to Mitchell's.  (I know, ice cream and gelato are different, but its the same craving)

Their fruit flavors are their strength, though I've never been disappointed.  And my number one favorite is the coconut, which is simply divine.
author: Jeff W.

description: Oh no!! The Night before Thanksgiving at 9:55pm, i suddenly realized i had forgotten my intended La Copa Loca run for Cinnamon gelato (the best) to go with my pumpkin tart! living just two blocks away, we called the Loca to check on their closing time, and the friendly folks agreed to stay open for us. La Copa Loca is Ze Best. tons of great flavors, (again, the cinnamon -- though green apple is great for summer) - and really friendly folks. the only sad La copa loca experience - i pulled that classic 6 year old move; was walking out with my cool, when a block from the shop, i knocked my gelato onto the sidewalk. :(
author: Dana W.

description: After spending a month touring through Europe, and discovering the simple joy of eating gelato while strolling though the streets of Vienna and Dubrovnik, I desperately looked for a great gelateria in the city. Thankfully, I didn't have to look farther than our favorite 22nd Street corridor of good eateries. I think we made a gelato run to La Copa Loca almost every night last summer. They are open late (bonus!) and have gelato that rival those we have tasted across the Atlantic. My partner favors stracchiatella, a sweet cream gelato with flakes of chocolate woven into it. I like to mix and match, but my favorites are mango and coconut - together. Can't wait for the hot weather to get here so I can stroll through the Mission with a cone and pretend that I am on the Stradun once again.
author: Rey L.

description: Mauro ROCKS!! His Gelato flavors have flava and he is a great guy to boot. VIVA ITALIA
author: Karen s.

description:
i wish i liked the gelato more then i did. am i completely spoiled by the fact that i became hard-core addicted to gelato the whole time i was in italy?
i found the texture to be more like sherbet here. it was super messy running down my hand. i couldn't eat it fast enough before it melted all over me.
ironically the flavor was good if not the texture. not too sweet. i tasted the teremisu (ok) but ended up with the blood orange due to all the rave reviews about it yelped here before me. it was orangey, but not intense/bloody like i wanted it to be. if you are into mild flavors then this place is for you.
i am going back to bombay ice creamery and double rainbow (my super faves), and when i can stand the crowd without wanting to punch anyone, bi-rite.
i only think i would go back to copa if i was right there in that part of the hood already. and i would order something like a shake...contained!
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description: This is the best gelateria in the Bay Area. Hands down. It's simple and authentic and tastes just like home. The gelato is light and flavorful, not too creamy or thick, like some of the gelato at fancyfied places. I'm actually looking into having them cater an event for me... just wish they had a location in the East Bay...
author: Happy N.

description: I've lived just down the street and one block over from this place for more than a year now, and was not swayed by the decorative ice cream cone outside for nearly all of this time (despite my love of model food as well as sweets). I think I must have just been under the spell of Maggie and her flea market of vegan ice cream containing allsorts of delicious concoctions. Anyway, one night I wanted to get out of the house and my desire for some ice cream was not enough to lead me up the big hill on my one-speed bike, so La Copa Loca it is. I mean, I go by this place every week, it's gelato, they have to have something vegan right? Since I was planning my rendevouz with a friend who has very high standards (he frequents the Castro gelato zone in addition to Ms. Mudd's), I stopped by on my way home from my weekly trip to Community Music Center to check out the goods and was not disappointed. Not only did the owner give me samples of many flavors with great enthusiasm, the fruits (particularly melon and blood orange) were delicate and the soy chocolate was not only available but it was totally rich and amazing. Friend swears it's the best he's ever had, and now I've got a super local source for fresh creamy delights (not sexual). Also how can you go wrong with a place that has a rotating display of ice cream fantasy worlds, like gelato tacos or pizza. My roommate says they've been chilling there for at least three years unchanged.
author: Jessalyn A.

description: I still give copa loca and the ice cream 4 stars but the gal who was working on 3/13/09 around 6 pm should get minus 4 stars for her poor customer service and surly attitude. I asked for a small gelato split into 2 flavors and she refused to do it so i had to get a medium. then when i asked for a second taste, she rolled her eyes like it was a big whoopdidoo. give me a break. if i wanted such a 'tude, i'd go to the marina.  even so, copa loca still gets my vote for mission gelato urges.
author: glitz g.

description: totally tasty tons of varieties gelato around the corner from my front door, wow, this is luxury!
author: James-Jimm P.

description: don't waste your time or your money...if you're in the city go to bi-rite creamery!!!!  truly worth the 20 minute wait time in line!
author: Monica O.

description: ok so priced well and quality is great! i gotta say i wish they had more of a seating selection but the area is a bit ruff and i grew up on 24th and mission .
author: Mauricio Fabian M.

description: The passion fruit gelato is beyond amazing!  And the chocolate is heavenly--really chocolately and creamy.  And I love the yogurt flavor--tangy and sweet.  You can't beat homemade gelato, even when it's a bit chilly outside.  Only sad thing is that they don't ALWAYS have passion fruit!  I've indulged in there sundaes as well and highly recommend that you do the same!  I heard a guy review the place on NPR for Frommers (I think) who said it was the best ice cream in the city--I have to agree.
author: Cristina J.

description: Oh yeah, now we're talking!!!  This is what S-E-R-V-I-C-E is supposed to be like.  I got a little bit of everything and if it weren't for being human and only having one stomach I'd still be here grazin' on Gelato!!  Mmmm mm Good.  Now if I could just move this to Chicago and actually make money from a cold confection in the winter time, I'd have it made.
author: Norberto Q.

description: I came across La Copa Loca at the Cinco de Mayo Festival at Dolores Park yesterday. The pineapple gelato was delicious. It was light, refreshing, and full of flavor. I can't wait to visit their store on 22nd Street.
author: Akemi F.

description: late nite gelato in the mission. Loves it.
author: pauline e.
